course_title: Spec. Topics in German Studies: Migration & Exile
class_notes:
(Same as JS 375 1)
According to the UN Refugee Agency, as of May 2023, more than 110 million people had been forcibly displaced worldwide "as a result of persecution, conflict, violence, human rights violations or events seriously disturbing public order." The number of refugees has doubled in the last ten years alone and continues to climb due to ongoing wars. Forced exile, the loss of home, family, friends, work, and/or livable environmental conditions are the reality for a significant proportion of the global population.
Through the lenses of different genres such as reportage, memoir, essay, novella, and film, this class explores the cultural productions of exile by German-Jewish writers who had to leave Germany due to Nazism in the 1930s. What thoughts, perspectives, and analyses on the rise of fascism did these writers develop? How did they conceive of their tasks as writers in exile? How did they make sense of and meaning from exile? How were forced migrations organized? What support networks were available to Jewish refugees? Special attention will be given to writers who were exiled to the Americas and to the ways in which relations of class, race, gender, and political affiliations intersect regarding their displacement from Germany and their resettlement elsewhere.
